top_categories.workout_context: Heck of the North's Snowmobile trails (roots, rocks), Minnesota Northwoods forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 100 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Heck of the North's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before September.
At mile 60 of 100, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
Heck of the North's technical snowmobile-trail gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Heck of the North, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Heck of the North. Train it until it feels boring.
At Heck of the North, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
When someone attacks on technical snowmobile-trail gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on technical snowmobile-trail gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Smooth pedaling at 100 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 4,500ft of climbing on technical snowmobile-trail gravel does to your power file on race day.
Two threshold sessions per week without the recovery cost of VO2max work. For 100 miles, sustainable FTP gains matter more than peak power.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Heck of the North’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Heck of the North demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride technical snowmobile-trail gravel at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: snowmobile trails (roots, rocks), minnesota northwoods forest roads, technical singletrack-width paths. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Durability to prepare you for 100 miles of technical snowmobile-trail gravel in Two Harbors, Minnesota.
